posts.title: Fragments of Shelley
posts.text: On May 4, 2021, a group of scholars and admirers of both Shelleys gathered online to celebrate a milestone in the editing of his poems: the appearance of Volume VII of The Complete Poetry of Percy Bysshe Shelley from the Johns Hopkins University Press, edited by Nora Crook. The online event is available for viewing.

posts.title: The Palimpsest of Justice: Law, Narrative, and the Romantic Self
posts.text: From 1750 to 1830, the legal landscape of Great Britain was significantly transformed. An accusatory form of trial gave way to an adversarial format—which was echoed in the periodical wars of the romantic press.

posts.title: A Black Tulip Comes to the Pforzheimer Collection, Part 2
posts.text: …To continue: you will recall that I was embarking on an attempt to explain the note at the bottom of p. 11 of Original Poetry by Victor and Cazire in the copy owned by the New York Public Library. To refresh your memory, here is the picture again—the note reads: Now for God's sake be secret / you will understand why I / wish you to be particularly so.

posts.title: A Black Tulip Comes to the Pforzheimer Collection
posts.text: Here at the Pforzheimer Collection, our big acquisition of the year is a black tulip, one of the rarest items in the Shelleyan world: Original Poetry by Victor and Cazire, 1810, Shelley's first book of verse. Lost to the public eye shortly after its publication and believed, till 1898, to have vanished altogether, only three other copies are known. Even the Bodleian Library, holder of the best Shelley collection in the world, does not own it.
